topic_page.title: Hormonal & Endocrine

intro.what_this_topic_means: This topic covers peptides and related agents discussed in endocrine pathways: growth hormone signaling, IGF axis, thyroid, appetite hormones, and broader hormone regulation.
common_misconceptions: Feeling effects quickly is not the same as long-term safety.
Hormone axes are regulated systems; pushing one lever can shift others.
Lack of side effects in the short term does not mean low risk.
who_should_be_extra_cautious: Adolescents and young adults (developing endocrine setpoints)
History of cancer or strong family risk (growth signaling uncertainty)
Uncontrolled diabetes, thyroid disease, or pituitary disorders

how_to_use_this_page: Topics help you browse; they do not recommend peptides.
Always check approval status and risk score first.
Evidence grade is shown to separate strong vs weak claims.

peptides.why_people_look_it_up: Often searched for GH/IGF signaling changes; human endocrine evidence exists but long-term outcomes are uncertain.

safety_callouts.title: Endocrine systems are interlocked
safety_callouts.body: Changing GH/IGF or appetite signaling can influence glucose handling, blood pressure, sleep, mood, and downstream hormone regulation. Treat uncertainty as part of risk.

evidence_notes.title: Evidence separation
evidence_notes.body: Preclinical signals can be interesting but do not guarantee human benefit. Look for human interventional evidence and clear safety reporting.
